manuscript.title: Münşeʾât (منشآت)
manuscript.author: Abdülkerîm Çelebi, Abdülkerîm b. Sinân el-Akhisârî (d. 1038/1629)
manuscript.notes: The zahriye (frontispiece) on f. 1a records the title as 'Münşeʾât-ı Kerîm Çelebi'. Section headings and terms such as 'nazm' and 'beyt' are rubricated (kırmızı mürekkep); text openings are also marked in red. Script: taʿlîk. Language: Turkish.

paper_decoration.summary: The YEK catalogue records the paper as 'mülevven kâğıt' (colored paper). Visual confirmation of p003 (IIIF screenshot) shows a slightly pinkish or warm-tinted paper tone distinguishable from standard cream — consistent with a lightly dyed mülevven ground. The color shift is subtle and digital images do not allow reliable classification of the dyestuff or precise hue. Identification rests primarily on the catalogue description; visual evidence is corroborating but not independently conclusive at available digital resolution.

catalogue_description.notes_field: 1a zahriyede eser adi 'Munse'at-i Kerim Celebi' seklinde kaydedilmistir. Basliklar ve 'nazm', 'beyt' gibi bazi ibareler kirmizi murekkepla yazilmistir. Soz baslari kirmizi murekkepla isaret edilmistir.

key_indicators: AH 1053 / CE 1643–44 dated copy of a Turkish epistolary collection: mid-17th-century Ottoman production context
Mülevven kâğıt paper: colored paper is a known luxury paper type in 17th-century Ottoman manuscript production
Taʿlîk script with rubricated headings: standard features of Ottoman inşâ texts of this period
cross_tradition_caveats: No workshop city stated; colored paper was used across Ottoman provinces as well as Istanbul
Subtle pinkish tint of the colored paper cannot be more precisely characterized from digital images alone

paper.description: Mülevven kâğıt — colored paper. The specific color is a pinkish or warm tone (lightly dyed; not deeply pigmented); color shift subtle at available digital resolution.

ruling.description: Not specified in catalogue. Rubricated section headings and text-opening markers noted.

binding.description: Miklebi onarılmış, yaldız şemseli, zencerekli, kahverengi meşin cilt. Brown leather (meşin) binding with gilt şemse (central medallion), zencirek (chain border), and a repaired mıklep (flap).

codicology.condition_summary: Binding mıklep has been repaired. Otherwise no damage reported in catalogue.
codicology.conservation_history: Mıklep (flap) repaired at an unspecified date.

limitations: Only one IIIF screenshot examined (p003); the subtle pinkish tint of the paper is consistent with mülevven but not distinguishable with certainty from slight aging or digitization color shift
Limiting factor: visual ambiguity — subtle color differentiation unreliable in digital images
No particle-level or pigment-level analysis possible from available images

elements.description: Paper has a slightly pinkish or warm-toned tint distinguishable from standard cream. Consistent with a lightly dyed colored (mülevven) paper. Color shift is subtle; digitization conditions and display calibration introduce uncertainty.

folio_analyses.notes: Visual evidence is corroborating but not independently conclusive. Classification relies primarily on the YEK catalogue's 'mülevven kâğıt' description.

terms_used.english: Colored/tinted paper: paper dyed or pigmented to produce a uniform or near-uniform color ground before writing; a recognized luxury paper category in Ottoman manuscript production
Collection of model letters, official documents, or prose compositions in the inşâ (chancery composition) tradition; a common Ottoman literary format
Frontispiece opening page, typically carrying the title and possibly ownership or donation inscriptions
Chain or interlinking loop border motif used on binding covers and occasionally in page framing

bibliography.citation: Blair, Sheila S. 'Color and Gold: The Decorated Papers Used in Manuscripts in Later Islamic Times.' Muqarnas 17 (2000): 24–36.
bibliography.relevance: Primary reference on colored (mülevven) and other decorated papers in later Islamic manuscripts; directly addresses the paper type recorded for this manuscript.

bibliography.citation: Gacek, Adam. The Arabic Manuscript Tradition: A Glossary of Technical Terms and Bibliography. Handbuch der Orientalistik, Erste Abteilung, Bd. 58. Leiden: Brill, 2001.
bibliography.relevance: Standard terminological reference for paper description, ruling, and manuscript format; useful for standardizing the description of this Ottoman inşâ manuscript.

bibliography.citation: Bloom, Jonathan M. Paper Before Print: The History and Impact of Paper in the Islamic World. New Haven: Yale University Press, 2001.
bibliography.relevance: Comprehensive history of Islamic paper production and decoration, providing context for the use of colored paper in 17th-century Ottoman manuscripts.

bibliography.citation: Déroche, François. Islamic Codicology: An Introduction to the Study of Manuscripts in Arabic Script. Translated by Deke Dusinberre and David Radzinowicz. London: Al-Furqan Islamic Heritage Foundation, 2005.
bibliography.relevance: Standard codicological reference for manuscript physical description, covering paper types, ruling, and binding conventions applicable to this Ottoman epistolary manuscript.

suggested_collections.institution: Süleymaniye Kütüphanesi — Âşir Efendi Koleksiyonu, Istanbul
suggested_collections.reason: The home collection. Other volumes in the Âşir Efendi Koleksiyonu may share similar paper treatments and binding styles.

provenance.waqf: Âşir Efendi Vakfı (inferred from collection name)
provenance.notes: Held in the Âşir Efendi Koleksiyonu at Süleymaniye Kütüphanesi, Istanbul. The title on the frontispiece (f. 1a) reads 'Münşeʾât-ı Kerîm Çelebi', confirming the attribution to Abdülkerîm Çelebi el-Akhisârî (d. 1038/1629). The copy is dated AH 1053 / CE 1643–44, approximately 14 years after the author's death.

analysis_metadata.image_source: YEK Portal IIIF — Süleymaniye Kütüphanesi Âşir Efendi Koleksiyonu (portal.yek.gov.tr); screenshot via visual-confirmation agent (Batch 3, 2026-02-26). yek_id: 198156, iiif_id: 0000000234074.
analysis_metadata.image_quality_notes: One IIIF screenshot examined (p003). The pinkish/warm tint of the paper is visible but subtle; reliable color classification is not possible from digital images alone. Overall confidence is limited by visual ambiguity inherent in subtle color differentiation at screen resolution.
folios_examined: p003 (IIIF — body text page, mülevven paper tint visible)
analysis_metadata.folios_not_examined: Zahriye (f. 1a with title inscription); opening text pages; all remaining folios. The extent of the colored paper programme across the volume has not been assessed visually.
